summary: Maurice Hyman Halperin was a former OSS official and Boston University professor suspected of Soviet espionage and working for the Soviet government. He is mentioned in connection to investigations into American Communists in Mexico and his relationship with individuals like James A. Perry, who was employed by the Agency. Halperin's file contains FBI and State Department documents, including reports and despatches related to him and associated individuals. The documents span from 1955 to 1962, indicating a period of scrutiny and investigation into his activities and connections.
significance: The significance of Maurice Hyman Halperin in the JFK context stems from the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) reviewing his file, suggesting a potential link, however tenuous, to the assassination investigation. His suspected ties to the Soviet government and connections to individuals under investigation for communist activities in Mexico may have prompted the HSCA to examine his records.
